q: What are the symptoms of a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: The main symptoms of a TIA can be remembered with the word FAST: Face - the face may have dropped on one side, the person may not be able to smile, or their mouth or eye may have dropped. Arms - the person may not be able to lift both arms and keep them raised because of weakness or numbness in one arm. Speech - their speech may be slurred or garbled, or the person may not be able to talk at all, despite appearing to be awake; they may also have problems understanding what you're saying to them. Time - it's time to call 999 immediately if you see any of these signs or symptoms.

q: When should I seek medical advice for a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: In the early stages of a TIA, it's not possible to tell whether you're having a TIA or a full stroke. It's important to call 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance if you or someone else has symptoms of a TIA or stroke. Even if the symptoms disappear while you're waiting for an ambulance to arrive, you still need to be assessed in hospital. You should be referred to see a specialist within 24 hours of the onset of your symptoms.

q: What causes a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: During a TIA, one of the blood vessels that supply your brain with oxygen-rich blood becomes blocked. This blockage is usually caused by a blood clot that's formed elsewhere in your body and traveled to the blood vessels supplying the brain, although it can also be caused by pieces of fatty material or air bubbles. Certain risk factors can increase your chances of having a TIA, such as smoking, high blood pressure, obesity, high cholesterol levels, regularly drinking an excessive amount of alcohol, having atrial fibrillation, and having diabetes.

q: How are transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs) treated?
a: Although the symptoms of a TIA resolve in a few minutes or hours, treatment is needed to help prevent another TIA or a full stroke happening in the future. Treatment will depend on your individual circumstances, such as your age and medical history. You're likely to be given advice about lifestyle changes to reduce your stroke risk and be offered medication to treat the cause of the TIA. In some cases, a surgery called a carotid endarterectomy may be needed to unblock your carotid arteries, the main blood vessels that supply your brain with blood.

q: How can I prevent a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: A TIA is often a sign that another one may follow, and you're at a high risk of having a full, life-threatening stroke in the near future. Regardless of whether you have had a TIA or stroke in the past, there are several ways you can lower your risk of having either in the future. These include maintaining a healthy weight, eating a healthy, balanced diet, doing regular exercise, limiting alcohol, and not smoking.

a: The symptoms of a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) include a dropped face on one side, weakness or numbness in one arm, slurred speech or garbled speech, and difficulty talking. It's important to call 999 immediately if you notice any of these signs or symptoms.

a: It's important to call 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance if you or someone else has symptoms of a TIA or stroke, even if the symptoms disappear. You should be assessed in the hospital within 24 hours of the onset of symptoms.

q: What causes a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: During a transient ischaemic attack (TIA), one of the blood vessels that supply the brain with oxygen-rich blood becomes blocked. This blockage is usually caused by a blood clot that formed elsewhere in the body and traveled to the brain's blood vessels.

q: What can increase the chances of having a TIA?
a: Certain factors can increase the chances of having a TIA, including smoking, high blood pressure, obesity, high cholesterol levels, excessive alcohol consumption, having atrial fibrillation, and diabetes. People over 55 years of age and people of Asian, African, or Caribbean descent are also at a higher risk.

q: How is a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) treated?
a: Although the symptoms of a TIA resolve in a few minutes or hours, treatment is necessary to prevent another TIA or a full stroke. Treatment depends on individual circumstances and may involve lifestyle changes, medication to treat the cause of the TIA, or a surgery called a carotid endarterectomy.

q: How can I prevent a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: To lower the risk of having a TIA or stroke, you can maintain a healthy weight, eat a balanced diet, engage in regular exercise, limit alcohol consumption, and refrain from smoking.

q: Is a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) a warning sign of a stroke?
a: Yes, a TIA is a warning sign that you may be at risk of having a full stroke in the near future. Seeking medical assessment after experiencing a TIA can help determine the best way to reduce the chances of a stroke.

q: What are the main symptoms of a TIA?
a: The main symptoms of a TIA can be remembered with the word FAST: Face drooping on one side, weakness or numbness in one arm, slurred or garbled speech, and time to call 999 immediately if any of these signs or symptoms are observed.

q: What should I do if I think I had a TIA previously but didn't seek medical advice?
a: If you think you may have had a TIA previously but didn't seek medical advice at the time, make an urgent appointment with a GP. They can assess your situation and determine whether a hospital assessment is necessary.

q: Is a TIA the same as a stroke?
a: A TIA is not the same as a stroke, although the symptoms can be similar. A TIA is caused by a temporary disruption in the blood supply to the brain, resulting in temporary symptoms that fully resolve within 24 hours. A stroke, on the other hand, causes lasting damage.
